Hi:
 The Yamanaka Newsletter is second to none as a useful source of compre=
hensive and detailed information on the Japanese sword - coming as a newsle=
tter it has certain natural limitations of easy use, ie, it isn't easy to u=
se, but it is virtually without peer.
 If you can latch onto one, do!
 AF

=



>>> jdz@... 08/04/05 11:21 AM >>>
I would strongly recommend additio=
nally:



Albert "Kozan" Yamanaka, reformatted by Paul R. Allman, The Nihon=
to Newsletters, 4 volumes, San Francisco: Northern California Japanese Swor=
d Club, (1994), 2004.



 

(Yoshikawa Kentaro, translated by Gordon Robson=
), (Nihon Token Hozon Kai) Novice Course, Northern California Japanese Swor=
d Club, 1990-1992.





The Northern California Club sends a copy of the No=
vice Course to all new members.

for the references!

  Mark


    -----Original Mes=
sage-----
    From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoo=

    Mark,

    I have both books. Yumoto's is a magn=
ificent pocket reference,
    although a bit dated. The Connoisseur's is a =
much more detailed
    reference, covering the same ground as Yumoto's, but=
 with more
    examples of every feature a nihonto can have. Curiously enou=
gh, every
    now and then I see it being offered on eBay, sometimes reachi=
ng bid
    amounts above 100 dollars. For the life of me, I can't understan=
d
    why. Not that the book isn't worth it, but because it's still
    ava=
ilable off the shelf at Amazon for less than 50 bucks:

  http://www.amazon=
.com/exec/obidos/redirect?path=3DASIN/4770020716&link_code=3Das
  2&camp=3D=
1789&tag=3Dlairofthenecr-20&creative=3D9325

    Now, that being said, the =
Connoisseur's is probably the best
    reference available in English. It p=
ales in comparison to published
    in Japan nihonto reference books which =
can make the Connoisseur's
    look like the pocket reference version.

   =
 Lastly, another book I found to be a good read, especially as it
    cover=
s nihonto manufacture, is The Craft of the Japanese Sword, by
    Leon Kapp=
, also available from Amazon:

  http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/redirect=
?path=3DASIN/087011798X&link_code=3Das
  2&camp=3D1789&tag=3Dlairofthenecr-=
20&creative=3D9325

    Hope that helps.

    Regards,

    Andres

08:39 AM 8/4/2005, you wrote:

enty of other venues to peddle this dvd.

't it.
    >THAT was the point Andres was trying to make.
    >
    >Just g=
ot John Yumoto's "The Samurai Sword" in the mail yesterday!  Any
    >suges=
tions out there for a must have "second" reference book? Just
  keeping
   =
 >things basic at this point. Not specializing in any one specific area
  y=
et.
    >Has anyone read "The Connoisseur's Book of Japoanese Swords"?
    =

    >Mark
